questions.question: Who was telling the story to Ronak and his friends?
questions.answer: Grandpa

questions.question: Where did the camel and the jackal live?
questions.answer: By a river

questions.question: What is the meaning of 'edge' in the story?

options.text: The border where one thing stops and another begins

questions.answer: The border or the line where one thing stops and another begins

questions.question: Which animal was described as 'very clever'?
questions.answer: The jackal

questions.question: What 'treat' did the jackal tempt the camel with?
questions.answer: Sugarcane

questions.question: How did the two friends cross the river?

options.text: The jackal sat on the camel's back

questions.answer: The jackal sat on the camel's back

questions.question: What did the jackal do after eating his fill?
questions.answer: He began to howl

questions.question: Why did the jackal howl?

options.text: He claimed it was his habit after a good dinner
He wanted to scare the camel

questions.answer: He was in the habit of singing (howling) after a good dinner

questions.question: What happened to the camel when the farmer came?

options.text: The farmer beat him up and drove him away
The farmer gave him more food

questions.answer: The farmer beat him up and drove him away

questions.question: Where did the camel start taking a dip?

options.text: Near the middle of the river

questions.answer: Near the middle of the river

questions.question: Why did the camel take a dip in the river?

options.text: To teach the jackal a lesson

questions.answer: To teach the jackal a lesson (Tit for Tat)

questions.question: What is the title of Grandpa's story?
questions.answer: Tit for Tat

questions.question: Which of these is a polite way to interrupt?
questions.answer: Pardon, Grandpa

questions.question: Which word is a noun from the story?
questions.answer: Camel

questions.question: Which word is a pronoun?
questions.answer: They

questions.question: What is a 'treat'?
questions.answer: A treat is something special that one enjoys

questions.question: Who said, 'Excuse me, Grandpa'?
questions.answer: Ronak

questions.question: Who explained what a 'sugarcane treat' meant?
questions.answer: Akshay

questions.question: How should you interrupt someone who is speaking?
questions.answer: Politely

questions.question: What is the noun for something we cannot touch or see?
questions.answer: Happiness

questions.question: What does a sentence always end with?

options.text: A full stop or question mark

questions.answer: A full stop or a question mark

questions.question: What does a sentence always start with?
questions.answer: A capital letter

questions.question: Which of these is a place noun?
questions.answer: Village

questions.question: What did Ishan guess 'edge' meant?
questions.answer: The border

questions.question: What did the jackal say he had a habit of doing after dinner?
questions.answer: Singing

questions.question: Who are the characters in Grandpa's story?
questions.answer: The characters are a camel and a jackal.

questions.question: Where did the camel and the jackal live?
questions.answer: They lived by a river, near the water's edge.

questions.question: What was located on the other side of the river?
questions.answer: There was a village with fields and farms.

questions.question: What word did Ronak ask for a definition of?
questions.answer: Ronak asked for the meaning of the word 'edge'.

questions.question: How did Ishan define the word 'edge'?
questions.answer: Ishan defined it as the border or the line where one thing stops and another begins.

questions.question: What was the camel doing when the jackal tried to play a trick?
questions.answer: The camel was happily munching away his food.

questions.question: What is the meaning of 'munching away'?
questions.answer: It means happily and slowly eating food.

questions.question: What did the jackal tempt the camel to do?
questions.answer: The jackal tempted him to go for a sugarcane treat in a farmer's field.

questions.question: How did Grandpa define a 'treat'?
questions.answer: A treat is something special that one enjoys.

questions.question: Did the camel agree to go for the treat immediately?
questions.answer: No, at first he hesitated, but in the end he agreed.

questions.question: How did the jackal get across the river?
questions.answer: He sat on the camel's back while the camel swam across.

questions.question: What did the two friends do in the field?
questions.answer: They ate their fill of sugarcane.

questions.question: What did the jackal do unexpectedly in the field?
questions.answer: Suddenly, the jackal began to howl.

questions.question: What did the camel say to try and stop the jackal?
questions.answer: He said, 'Sssh! You will wake the farmer.'

questions.question: Who came running to the field because of the howling?
questions.answer: The farmer and his helpers came running.

questions.question: What did the jackal do when the farmer arrived?
questions.answer: The naughty jackal slipped away.

questions.question: What happened to the camel when the farmer caught him?
questions.answer: The farmer beat him up and drove him away.

questions.question: Where was the jackal when the camel returned to the river?
questions.answer: The jackal was waiting for the camel at the riverside.

questions.question: What reason did the jackal give for howling?
questions.answer: He said he was in the habit of singing after a good dinner.

questions.question: How did the camel react to the jackal's apology at the riverside?
questions.answer: He didn't say anything and let the jackal sit on his back to cross the river.

questions.question: What was the water like in the middle of the river?
questions.answer: The water was very deep.

questions.question: What did the camel do in the deep water?
questions.answer: The camel began to take a dip in the river.

questions.question: Why was the jackal frightened in the river?
questions.answer: He was afraid the camel was trying to drown him.

questions.question: What did the camel say to the jackal in the river?
questions.answer: He said he was in the habit of taking a dip in the river after a good meal.

questions.question: Did the jackal learn a lesson?
questions.answer: Yes, he learnt his lesson and never troubled the camel again.

questions.question: What is the English name for words like 'I, we, you, he, she, it, they'?
questions.answer: They are called pronouns.

questions.question: What do pronouns stand for?
questions.answer: Pronouns are words that stand for nouns.

questions.question: Give two examples of polite interruptions from the box.
questions.answer: 'Pardon,' and 'Excuse me, Sir/Madam'.

questions.question: What should you say if you didn't hear the last word someone said?
questions.answer: 'Sorry, but I did not get the last word / sentence.'

questions.question: What are nouns?
questions.answer: Nouns are naming words for people, animals, places, or things.

questions.question: Name two nouns that refer to 'People' from the chapter.
questions.answer: Grandpa and farmer (or friends, helpers, Radhika).

questions.question: Name two nouns that refer to 'Animals' from the chapter.
questions.answer: Camel and jackal.

questions.question: Name two nouns that refer to 'Places' from the chapter.
questions.answer: Village and field (or farm, river).

questions.question: Give an example of a noun for something we can feel or see.
questions.answer: Stick, water, or sugarcane.

questions.question: Give an example of a noun for something we cannot touch or see.
questions.answer: Happiness, habit, trick, or time.

questions.question: What is a 'response' when someone says 'Excuse me'?
questions.answer: A response can be 'Yes?', 'Sure', or 'Certainly'.

questions.question: What does Gauri ask Grandpa about the story?
questions.answer: Gauri asks if it means the animals were going to steal from the farmer.

questions.question: Why did Shreya want the questions to be held later?
questions.answer: She wanted to listen to the rest of the story first.

questions.question: What is the first rule for writing a sentence mentioned in the book?
questions.answer: The first letter of a sentence is always a capital letter.

questions.question: What punctuation can a sentence end with?
questions.answer: A sentence can end with a full stop or a question mark.

questions.question: What is the equivalent of 'Tit for Tat' in your mother tongue?
questions.answer: (This varies by language, e.g., in Hindi: 'Jaise ko taisa').

questions.question: Is 'Jackal' a proper noun or a common noun in the table?
questions.answer: It is listed under 'Animals' as a noun.

questions.question: Who said, 'Can you / Could you repeat that, please?'
questions.answer: This is a suggested expression for polite interruptions.

questions.question: How did the camel describe the jackal's behavior in the river?
questions.answer: He called him a 'silly fellow'.

questions.question: What did Vidya ask for?
questions.answer: She asked Grandpa to repeat the last words because she didn't get them.

questions.question: What did Radhika want Grandpa to repeat?
questions.answer: Radhika asked him to repeat the last phrase 'happily munching away'.

questions.question: How many friends were listening to Grandpa's story?
questions.answer: The story mentions Ronak, Ishan, Radhika, Vidya, Akshay, Gauri, and Shreya (at least 7).

questions.question: What is 'howling'?
questions.answer: Howling is the long, loud cry of a jackal or wolf.

questions.question: Why did the jackal slip away easily?
questions.answer: He was small and naughty (clever).

questions.question: Why could the camel not slip away?
questions.answer: The camel is a large animal and could not move as quickly or hide easily.
